docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
BirdDog is a powerful & extensible research tool used by sales people to maximize revenue at their organization.

The BirdDog Documentations is broken into three sections:

  • Quick Start Guide explains how you can build a repeatable, winning workflow in BirdDog in under an hour.
  • Application Docs are an overvieew of how to get the most value out of BirdDog. Most users start here.
  • User Docs are very specific, technical instructions on how to use the platform.
Is BirdDog useful for non sales people?

While most of the BirdDog users are sales people, the tool works great for many other things, like monitoring state legislation, watching university grant programs, & staying up to date on what your competitors or partners are up to, to name a few.

For additional support, contact us at hello@getbirddog.ai

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Account Suggestions Page is BirdDog's strategic "air traffic control." Powered by Farsight (our proprietary account finder), this page surfaces high-intent, high-fit companies that you aren't currently tracking but should be. It bridges the gap between a cold lead and an active opportunity by providing a constant stream of "lookalike" recommendations based on your successful signals.

docs.title: The Assignment Desk (0:00 – 0:38)
docs.text: The Desk is where managers and reps view and act on recommendations. * Identify Opportunity: See which signals a recommended account is hitting (e.g., "Expanding Sales Team") and read a summary of the intent. * Assign to Reps: Move an account from a recommendation to a monitored state by assigning it to a specific team member. * Scale: The system can pull in thousands of recommendations, ensuring your team never runs out of warm prospects.

docs.title: Farsight Setup Modes (0:57 – 1:50)
docs.text:
To generate these recommendations, you must configure Farsight in the Settings menu. You have two primary operating modes:

  1. My List Mode: Upload a massive list (CSV/CRM export) and let BirdDog "clean" it—identifying only the accounts that match your high-intent signals.
  2. Entire Internet Mode: BirdDog crawls the web to find net-new accounts that match your ICP and exhibit your chosen signals.

docs.title: Configuration Requirements
docs.text: Regardless of the mode, Farsight requires at least one signal set to "High" (Green). * Signal Weight: BirdDog will only recommend accounts that trigger at least one of your High-priority signals. * Pro-Tip: Adding more High signals increases the volume and diversity of your recommendations.

docs.title: Mode 1: My List Setup (2:29 – 4:48)
docs.text: Use this to filter a raw lead list or a stagnant CRM database. * Upload: Drop in a list of URLs (recommended: 1,000+ for best results). * Parameters: Set filters for employee count, headquarters location, and specific industries. * Auto-Add & Replace: * Set a Point Threshold (e.g., 10 points) for accounts to be added automatically to your main list. * Use Replace to automatically swap out low-scoring accounts (<10 points) with new high-scoring finds.

docs.title: Mode 2: Entire Internet Setup (4:54 – 7:59)
docs.text:
This acts as your automated lead generation engine.

Feature Description Lookalike Modeling Finds accounts that "look like" your current best customers. Employee Count Set hard limits (e.g., 5–200) based on LinkedIn data. Geography Filter by region, country, or specific U.S. states. Industry Guardrails Include specific niches or exclude competitors/non-ICP industries.

Processing Note: Farsight runs daily. After initial setup, expect to see your first batch of recommendations within 2 hours.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: The "Auto-Pilot" Workflow
docs.text: Enable Auto-Add with a Replace threshold. This creates a self-healing pipeline where BirdDog proactively "fires" your worst accounts and "hires" the most qualified prospects on the internet without you lifting a finger.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Adding accounts is the first step toward generating high-intent signals. BirdDog is designed to be flexible—you can add a single target or a bulk list of hundreds of companies in seconds. Once added, BirdDog’s engine begins crawling for specific triggers and calculating the intent scores for your new prospects.

docs.title: How to Add Accounts (0:00 – 0:35)
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the My Accounts page.
  2. Click the Add Accounts button in the top right.
  3. Input your list: Paste company URLs directly into the field.
    • No Formatting Needed: You can copy-paste directly from Excel, Google Sheets, or a raw text file. Commas or special separators are not required.
  4. Select Target List (Admins only): If you are an admin, choose which team member or specific list these accounts should be assigned to.
  5. Submit: Click Add Accounts to trigger the research process.

Processing Time: Accounts typically take between 20 minutes and 1 hour to fully populate with data and signals. You will know an account is finished once a Point Score appears next to it.

docs.title: Managing Capacity (0:44 – 1:04)
docs.text:
Every BirdDog license has a specific capacity for tracked accounts. The status bar at the top of the "Add Accounts" window provides a real-time view of your limits:

  • Tracking Limit: The total number of accounts your plan allows you to monitor simultaneously.
  • Available to Add: The number of slots you have left before reaching your cap.
  • Archive/Delete Recommendation: If you are at capacity, the system will show you how many accounts you need to Archive or Delete to make room for new targets.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: Swapping Accounts
docs.text: BirdDog allows you to "swap" your list. If an account is no longer a priority, you can archive it to immediately free up a seat for a new high-potential URL. This allows you to keep your pipeline fresh without necessarily increasing your total seat count.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: BirdDog is built for collaboration. Whether you are onboarding a new AE, an SDR, or a Sales Manager, the System Setup page allows you to control exactly what each user can see and do within the platform. Adding a user triggers an automated welcome email with their credentials and onboarding documentation.

docs.title: User Roles & Permissions (0:22 – 2:00)
docs.text:
BirdDog offers three distinct user types to match your team’s structure:

Role Access Level Best For... Normal Can add and manage their own account lists. Can optionally be granted Admin rights to see System Setup/Assignment Desk. AEs & Full-Cycle Reps. Most users (99%) should be set up with this role. View-Only Cannot add or edit accounts. They must be assigned to "follow" a specific Normal user's list. SDRs/BDRs who are paired with an AE and need to research their partner's book of business. Manager Full visibility across the entire team’s accounts and progress. Automatic Admin access to the Assignment Desk and System Setup. Sales Leaders & RevOps who need a "God View" but aren't actively working individual deals.

docs.title: How to Add a User (0:12 – 2:15)
docs.text:
1. Navigate to System Setup in the bottom-left sidebar.
  2. Click the Add a User button.
  3. Choose the Role: Select from Normal, View-Only, or Manager.
  4. Enter Email: Input the user's professional email address.
  5. Configure Visibility: * If adding a Normal user, choose if they should be able to view other teammates' accounts.
    • If adding a View-Only user, select the specific teammate they are supporting.
  6. Admin Toggle: For Normal users, choose "Yes" or "No" for Admin access. Admins can access:
    • Assignment Desk (Farsight recommendations)
    • Assignment Progress (Team performance)
    • System Setup (Integrations and Signals)
  7. Submit: Click Create.

docs.title: Onboarding Experience
docs.text: Once you click Create, BirdDog automatically handles the rest: * Welcome Email: The new user receives an email with their login credentials. * Support Resources: The email includes help documentation to get them up to speed quickly. * Immediate Access: They can log in and begin researching accounts right away.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: The SDR/AE Pairing
docs.text: To get the most out of the View-Only role, pair your SDR with their specific AE. This keeps the SDR’s view clean and focused strictly on the accounts their AE is currently targeting, preventing any crossover or confusion in the outreach process.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: If your Account Suggestions is surfacing accounts that don't quite hit your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP), you can tune the Account Finder engine to be more restrictive. Refining your recommendations ensures that your team spends time only on the most exciting, high-fit opportunities.

docs.title: 1. Instant Feedback (0:22 – 0:38)
docs.text: On the Account Suggestions page, you can "Deny" any account that doesn't fit. * The Action: Click deny and select a reason (e.g., "Not ICP"). * The Result: This sends direct feedback to the BirdDog team to help improve our underlying models for your specific account.

docs.title: 2. Global Filter Adjustments (0:39 – 3:38)
docs.text:
For a broader fix, adjusting your Farsight settings is the most effective way to eliminate irrelevant leads.

  • Signal Calibration: Farsight only recommends accounts that trigger at least one "High" (Green) signal.
    • The Fix: If results are too broad, reduce the number of signals marked as "High." Only tag your "top-tier" criteria as High to prevent lower-quality data from pulling in irrelevant accounts.
  • Hard Firmographic Limits: These filters are absolute (based on LinkedIn data):
    • Employee Count: Set a strict range (e.g., 5–200) to stop seeing companies that are too small or too enterprise.
    • Geography: Restrict recommendations to specific countries, regions, or even individual U.S. states to match your sales territories.
    • Industry Inclusion/Exclusion: Specifically include your "bread and butter" industries or use the Exclude feature to block competitors or non-fit sectors.

docs.title: Managing Old vs. New Recommendations (3:39 – 4:08)
docs.text: When you update your filters and click Save and Run, BirdDog applies those rules to all future searches. * Existing Leads: Any accounts already on your Assignment Desk will remain there. They are not automatically deleted. * Full Reset: If you want a completely fresh start based on your new filters, reach out to our support team, and we can wipe your current account suggestions to make room for the new, refined recommendations.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: The "Signal Audit"
docs.text: If you have more than 5–7 signals marked as "High," you are likely casting too wide a net. Audit your Signals page and demote secondary triggers to "Low" importance to force Farsight to find only the "Slam Dunk" prospects.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Archiving is a critical feature for managing your BirdDog capacity without losing historical data. When you archive an account, BirdDog pauses monitoring for that company. This freezes the signals and scores at their current state and, most importantly, frees up a tracking seat so you can add new accounts to your system.

docs.title: Why Archive? (0:00 – 0:21)
docs.text:
• Capacity Management: Every BirdDog plan has a limit on "active" tracked accounts. Archiving allows you to swap out cold prospects for new ones.
  • Data Retention: Unlike deleting, archiving preserves the "Why Now" summaries and signal history you've already gathered.
  • Temporary Pause: If a deal goes dark, archive the account to save resources, then reactivate it later to resume live monitoring.

docs.title: For Sales Reps (0:40 – 0:52)
docs.text: Manage your personal book of business directly from the My Accounts page: 1. Identify Targets: Look at the top of the page to see how many accounts you need to archive to make room for new ones. 2. Selection: Check the boxes next to the accounts you wish to pause. 3. Action: Click the Archive button.

docs.title: For Admins & Managers (0:53 – 1:13)
docs.text: Manage account capacity across the entire team from the System Setup: 1. Navigate to System Setup → Manage Accounts. 2. Filter & Select: Use filters (such as "Low Score" or "Specific Owner") to identify accounts that should be paused. 3. Bulk Archive: Select the accounts and click Archive.

docs.title: What Happens to an Archived Account?
docs.text:
• Monitoring Stops: BirdDog will no longer crawl job boards, news, or filings for that company.
  • Scores are Frozen: The Point Score will remain at the last recorded value.
  • Seat Freed: One slot is immediately added back to your "Available to Add" count.
  • Reactivation: You can search your archived list at any time and click Activate to resume live monitoring.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: The Capacity Indicator
docs.text: Keep an eye on the message at the top of your dashboard. If it says "You can archive X number of accounts to add more," it means you are nearing your tracking limit. Use this as a trigger to audit your list and archive accounts that haven't shown signal activity in the last 30 days.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Plays are pre-saved, dynamic filters that allow you to segment your book of business based on specific buying personas or sales strategies. Instead of manually filtering your accounts every day, Plays act as automated "buckets" that instantly surface accounts matching your specific criteria—such as "Expansion Opportunities" or "New Sales Leadership."

docs.title: How to Create a New Play (0:29 – 3:15)
1. Name & Description
docs.text: Click Create new play and define your objective. * Example: "Startups Formalizing" * Description: "Hiring first sales rep or recently funded."

docs.title: 2. CRM Stage Filters
docs.text: You can choose to limit your play to specific stages in your pipeline (Closed-Lost, Discovery, etc.). * Net New: Leave this blank to focus on accounts not yet in your active sales cycle. * Expansion: Filter for "Closed-Won" deals to identify existing customers with new growth signals.

docs.title: 3. Signal Logic: OR vs. AND vs. NOT
docs.text: This is the engine of your Play. You can layer signals using three types of logic: * OR Signals (Broadest): Surfaces accounts that have at least one of the selected signals. (e.g., "Funding Round" OR "New Sales Leader"). * AND Signals (Narrowest): Surfaces only accounts that have all selected signals. * NOT Signals (Exclusion): Prevents accounts with certain triggers from appearing in the Play.

docs.title: 4. Firmographic Guardrails
docs.text: Refine your play with specific company data: * Employee Count: Limit the size of companies (e.g., 10–100 employees). * Geography: Include or exclude specific countries or U.S. states. * Industry: Target specific sectors like "Software" or "Financial Services."

docs.title: Accessing Your Results (3:16 – 3:30)
docs.text: Once created, your Play appears as a card on the main dashboard. * Real-time Updates: As BirdDog finds new signals across your account list, those companies will automatically populate the relevant Plays. * Deep Dive: Click into any Play card to view the specific accounts and their corresponding signals.

docs.title: Popular Play Examples
docs.text:
• The "Re-Engagement" Play: CRM Stage = Closed-Lost + Signal = New Sales Leader (OR) Funding Round.
  • The "First Sales Hire" Play: Signal = First Enterprise Salesperson (AND) Employee Count < 50.
  • The "Market Expansion" Play: Geography = Western Europe + Signal = Hiring Multiple Salespeople.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: The Logic Balance
docs.text: Most successful teams use OR logic for their primary Plays to ensure a healthy volume of prospects. Use AND logic only for highly specialized "Sniper" campaigns where multiple conditions must be met before outreach.

docs.title: Support
docs.text: Need help architecting a complex "AND" logic Play or syncing stages from your CRM? 📧 hello@getbirddog.ai

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: As your sales strategy evolves, you may find that certain Plays are no longer applicable or that you have created duplicate filters. Keeping your Plays dashboard organized ensures your team stays focused on the most current and effective outreach strategies.

docs.title: How to Delete a Play (0:23 – 0:45)
docs.text:
Removing an outdated or duplicate Play is a quick process that helps declutter your workspace:

  1. Identify the Play: Locate the card on your main dashboard that you wish to remove.
  2. Access Options: Click on the three dots (⋮) in the top right corner of the specific Play card.
  3. Confirm Deletion: Select the delete option and confirm your choice.
  4. Instant Removal: The Play card will be immediately removed from your dashboard.

docs.title: When to Delete a Play
docs.text:
• Duplicates: If you accidentally created two versions of the same signal filter (e.g., "Expansion Opportunities").
  • Strategy Shifts: If you are no longer targeting a specific segment (e.g., you’ve moved from Startups to Enterprise).
  • Errors: If the logic (AND/OR) was set up incorrectly and it's faster to restart than to edit.

docs.title: Important Considerations
docs.text:
• Account Data is Safe: Deleting a Play does not delete the accounts or signals within BirdDog; it simply removes the saved filter view.
  • Irreversible: Once a Play is deleted, you will need to manually recreate the filters, logic, and firmographic settings if you want it back.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: Clean Your Dashboard
docs.text: We recommend auditing your Plays at the start of every quarter. If a Play hasn't surfaced a new account in 30 days, it’s likely too narrow or the strategy has aged—archive the thought and delete the card to make room for fresh search criteria.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: As your sales strategy evolves, you may find that certain triggers are no longer relevant to your outreach. Deleting a signal ensures your dashboard stays clean and that you stop receiving notifications for data points that aren't driving value for your team.

docs.title: How to Delete a Signal (0:00 – 0:22)
docs.text:
The process is straightforward and managed through the central signal configuration area:

  1. Navigate to System Setup from the bottom-left sidebar.
  2. Go to Signals → Configure Signals.
  3. Locate the signal you wish to remove from your active list.
  4. Click the Trashcan icon next to the signal name.
  5. Confirm the action by clicking Yes in the pop-up window.

docs.title: What Happens After Deletion? (0:23 – 0:32)
docs.text:
Deleting a signal triggers an automated cleanup across your entire platform:

  • Removal from Accounts: Over the following hour, the system will strip that specific signal data from all accounts in your organization.
  • Notification Stop: You will immediately stop receiving alerts (Email, Slack, or In-App) for that specific trigger.
  • Point Score Recalculation: Deleting a signal may result in a slight shift in your account scores, as that criteria is no longer being factored into the intent ranking.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: Delete vs. Mute
docs.text: If you think you might need the signal again in the future, consider muting the notifications or setting the importance to Low instead of deleting it. Deletion is permanent; if you change your mind later, you will need to recreate the signal question and wait for the system to re-scan all your accounts.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: To ensure maximum speed and stability in account filtering, BirdDog Plays are currently "static" once created. If you need to refine your logic, add a new signal, or change the employee count range for an existing Play, the most efficient method is to delete and recreate the Play.

docs.title: The "Edit" Workflow (0:00 – 0:31)
docs.text:
Since there is no direct "Edit" button for an active Play, follow these steps to adjust your strategy:

  1. Note Your Criteria: Briefly review your current Play to note which signals or CRM stages you want to keep.
  2. Delete the Old Play: Click the three dots (⋮) on the Play card and confirm deletion (this declutters your dashboard for the new version).
  3. Re-Run Setup: Click Create New Play and follow the standard setup wizard:
    • CRM Stages: Adjust which deal stages should be included.
    • Signal Logic: Refine your OR/AND/NOT logic.
    • Firmographics: Update employee counts, geography, or industry filters.
  4. Save & Run: Your new, adjusted Play will immediately begin scanning your accounts.

docs.title: Why Recreating is Better Than Editing
docs.text:
• Clean Data Pull: Recreating the Play triggers a fresh scan of your account list against the new parameters, ensuring no outdated data is "cached."
  • Logic Verification: It forces a quick review of your OR/AND logic, which is where most filtering errors occur.
  • Dashboard Organization: It prevents "filter bloat" by ensuring you only have active, optimized Plays on your Assignment Desk.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: Iterative Testing
docs.text: If a Play is returning too many accounts, recreate it using AND logic for your signals. If it’s returning too few, recreate it using OR logic and broaden your firmographic ranges (e.g., increasing the employee count limit).

docs.title: General
docs.text:
What is BirdDog and how does it work? BirdDog monitors public signals (news, job postings, company sites, filings, earnings calls/reports, social) for your target accounts. You define Signals (questions you want BirdDog to answer about accounts), and BirdDog surfaces matches with source links, summaries, and next-step actions. Farsight improves your account list over time by replacing weak accounts with stronger ones.

How does BirdDog find buying signals? It continuously crawls and analyzes public data, matching it to your Signals. When a match is found (e.g., “hiring multiple AEs” or “new CRO”), BirdDog summarizes why it matters and links to the original source.

What data sources does BirdDog use? Press releases, news sites, company websites, job boards/postings, SEC/financial filings, earnings calls/reports, and certain social/professional sources. You can see source links on each signal.

How often is account and signal data refreshed? BirdDog refreshes daily; Farsight recommendations and account rescoring also update nightly.

Can I integrate BirdDog with my CRM (HubSpot, Salesforce, etc.)? Yes. From an account, you can jump directly to CRM records (HubSpot/Salesforce). To set this up, email hello@getbirddog.ai or reach out to the team in your Slack channel.

What keyboard shortcuts should I know to work faster? - Enter: Open Next Steps / advance the current signal - I: Open account’s LinkedIn page - D: Dismiss a signal in Signals view - Y / N: Accept / Dismiss Farsight recommendations

docs.title: Accounts & Credits
docs.text:
What are BirdDog credits? Credits are monthly allowances to add/replace accounts being actively monitored. Each active account consumes capacity; credits let you swap in new ones.

How do credits reset each month? They reset automatically at the start of your billing cycle. You’ll see your credits available and accounts you can add now in Account Manager.

What happens if I hit my account limit? You won’t be able to add new accounts until you archive some existing ones (freeing capacity, when available) or your credits reset.

How do I archive accounts to free up space? In Account Manager, select accounts → Archive. Archived accounts stop daily monitoring and free up capacity for new adds.

What’s the difference between deleting and archiving accounts? - Archive: Keeps history but pauses monitoring (recommended). - Delete: Removes the account permanently from your tenant (use cautiously).

How do I upload new accounts into BirdDog? In Account Manager → paste one or more company URLs (or a CSV list) into the input → choose the target list → Add.

Can I upload accounts from tools like Apollo or ZoomInfo? Yes. Export domains/URLs from those tools and paste/upload into BirdDog (Account Manager or Farsight My List Mode).

Why do some accounts show a score of 0? They’re newly added or still scraping. Scores typically appear within ~20-60 minutes as BirdDog ingests and analyzes sources.

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
What are lists in BirdDog? Lists are buckets of accounts that you can target with different Signals or strategies (e.g., Enterprise, Healthcare, EMEA).

How do I create a new list? In Account Manager → Lists panel → Create (name the list). (If you don’t see Create, you may lack permissions—ask an admin.)

Can accounts belong to multiple lists? Yes. A domain can live in more than one list (e.g., Master + Enterprise).

How do I rename or delete a list? In Account Manager → Lists panel → choose list → Rename or Delete. Deleting a list doesn’t delete the accounts globally; it removes the list container.

Can I export a list of accounts? Yes. Use checkboxes to select accounts → Export (CSV).

What’s the best way to organize lists (by industry, region, team)? Use segments you’ll actually filter by: enterprise vs. mid-market, regions (NA/EU), or verticals (SaaS/Healthcare). Keep it simple and aligned to territory owners.

docs.title: Signals
docs.text:
What is a signal in BirdDog? A question BirdDog answers about your accounts (e.g., “Does the account mention hiring multiple sales roles?”). When true, BirdDog creates an alert with summary + sources.

How do I create a new signal? On Signals page → input box → phrase your question (start with Does / Is) → choose target list → title it → Add.

What’s the best way to write a good signal? - Start with Does/Is (clear boolean framing) - Anchor to behaviors (hiring, leadership changes, tooling, geography) - Add disqualifiers (e.g., exclude recruiters) - Keep it specific and test iteratively

What are disqualifying signals? Rules that remove noise (e.g., “Exclude recruiting agencies”). Add as negative filters to keep your feed clean.

How do I mute a signal? On Signals page, toggle Mute to stop Slack/Email/Teams notifications (the signal still runs/accumulates results).

What does signal priority do? It influences account rankings and Farsight recommendations. High priority signals weigh more heavily in scoring.

How do I connect signals to email templates? Create templates in Settings or Team Page → on Signals, associate a template to prefill suggested outreach when a match occurs.

Can I edit or delete a signal later? Yes. Click Edit to change wording/title/priority/context; Delete to remove entirely.

How do BirdDog Context refinements work? Use the Context field (a free-form prompt) to teach BirdDog nuance (e.g., “Only show US/EU and junior roles”). Update as you learn.

How many signals should I create? Start with 10–15 per team (mix of positive buying cues + disqualifiers). Add more once you see which ones perform.

docs.title: Farsight
docs.text:
What is Farsight? BirdDog’s recommendation engine that improves your account list by promoting strong-fit accounts and demoting/removing weak ones.

What is the difference between My List Mode and Entire Internet Mode? - My List Mode: You upload a list (up to 10k domains). Farsight cleans, scores, and replaces poor performers. - Entire Internet Mode: You set ICP parameters (size, geo, sector). BirdDog finds net-new lookalikes across the web.

How do I upload a list for Farsight to clean? In Farsight → My List Mode → upload company URLs (CSV or paste) → set thresholds (e.g., replace <10 with >30 points) → Save & Run.

What is Auto-Add in Farsight? A rule that automatically inserts recommended accounts when they meet your thresholds (score, signals, list cap).

Can Farsight replace low-scoring accounts automatically? Yes. Configure replacement thresholds (e.g., remove <10 pts when a >30 pt alternative appears) and enable Auto-Add.

How often does Farsight update recommendations? It reviews and recommends nightly when there are under 20 recommendations waiting, with ongoing refreshes as new signals appear.

What’s the best way to set thresholds in Auto-Add? - Start conservative: add only >30 points with at least one high-priority signal - Respect list caps - Tune after a week based on quality

docs.title: Account Manager
docs.text:
What is the Account Manager page used for? To add, archive, delete, export, filter, and organize accounts into lists. It’s your operational control center.

How do I filter accounts in Account Manager? Use the filter button (by name, list, status, score, signal presence, location, size). Combine filters for precise selections.

How do I bulk archive or delete accounts? Select via checkboxes → choose Archive or Delete in bulk actions. Archiving is safest for capacity management.

Can I upload accounts directly into Account Manager? Yes. Paste URLs or upload a CSV into the input box, pick a target list, then Add.

How do account scores update after adding them? BirdDog scrapes and scores within ~20 minutes; scores then evolve as new signals arrive.

docs.title: Team Management
docs.text:
How do I invite a new user to BirdDog? On Team Page → Invite New User → enter email → assign accounts → (optional) include org signals/templates → Create → Send Email.

How do I allocate accounts to users? In the user table, set Allocated Accounts for each user. Adjust anytime to match usage.

What happens if a user isn’t using all their accounts? Lower their allocation to free capacity for others or Farsight. You can raise it again later.

Can I reassign accounts from one user to another? Yes. Archive from User A and add to User B; or use admin tools to move account/list ownership (depending on your plan/permissions).

How do I send onboarding emails to new users? After creating the user, click Send Email to dispatch login details, tips, and getting-started guides.

Can I share signals with my whole team? Yes. Use Organization Signals on the Team Page to publish a signal template to all users.

How do organization-wide templates work? Admins create signal and email templates once and push them to all users, ensuring consistent strategy and messaging.

Can admins see all user activity? Admins can see user allocations/usage and outcomes associated with accounts/signals. For deeper audit trails, contact support for plan capabilities.

docs.title: Email Templates
docs.text:
How do I create an email template in BirdDog? On Team Page (or Settings for non-admins) → Create Email Template → add Title, Example, and Template (with variables) → Save.

How do I connect an email template to a signal? On the Signals page, choose the signal → Link Template. When the signal fires, your template is ready with context.

Can email templates be shared across the whole team? Yes. Create them as organization templates on the Team Page and apply them to org-wide signals.

Can I edit or delete an email template? Yes. Open the template → Edit or Delete. Edits apply to future uses (past messages remain unchanged).

What’s the difference between example emails and templates? - Example: A sample for guidance. - Template: A reusable, parametrized message tied to Signals.

docs.title: Notifications
docs.text:
What notifications can BirdDog send (Slack, Teams, Email)? Signal alerts can be delivered to Slack, Microsoft Teams, and Email.

How do I mute or unmute notifications for a signal? On Signals page, toggle Mute for that signal (alerts stop; the signal still runs).

docs.title: Shortcuts & Productivity
docs.text:
What does pressing Enter on the keyboard do? Opens Next Steps and advances your workflow for the current signal.

What does pressing I do? Opens the account’s LinkedIn page.

What does pressing Y or N do in Farsight? Y accepts and adds the recommended account; N dismisses it.

What does pressing D do in Signals view? Dismisses the current signal and advances to the next.

Are there other keyboard shortcuts I should know? Those are the core ones. Shortcuts may expand over time; check the in-app Need Help link for updates.

docs.title: Data & Sources
docs.text:
Where does BirdDog pull its information from? Public web sources: press/news, company sites, job posts, filings, earnings, and select social/professional platforms.

How reliable are the sources BirdDog uses? Signals include source links so you can verify context yourself. BirdDog summarizes but never hides the original source.

Can I see the sources behind each signal? Yes. Every signal shows linked sources used to generate the summary.

How does BirdDog summarize source data? It extracts the relevant snippet, builds a concise summary, and highlights why it matters (e.g., hiring surge, leadership change).

Can I customize which sources BirdDog looks at? You can steer what it looks for via Signals and context. Source-level whitelisting/blacklisting may depend on plan; ask support.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
How many accounts should I actively manage at once? Focus on what your reps can truly work (e.g., 50–200 each, depending on motion). Use Farsight to keep quality high.

How many signals should I create per team? Start with 10–15 (mix of buying cues + disqualifiers). Iterate weekly based on performance.

How often should I clean/archive accounts? At least monthly (credit reset). Use Farsight’s replacement rules to automate cleanup.

How should I prioritize signals for the best results? Mark critical triggers as High (e.g., “hiring multiple AEs,” “new CRO,” “new funding/market entry”). Tie to your strongest templates.

How should I set thresholds in Farsight for my industry? Start Score >30 with at least 1 high-priority signal. Adjust by observed quality (raise the bar if SDRs complain about fit).

What’s the best workflow for working signals daily? Open Signals view → sort by recency/priority → Enter to work → Generate message → push to CRM → D to dismiss → repeat.

How can BirdDog help me find “hidden” opportunities? Use creative Signals (e.g., “pilot program,” “POC,” “migration,” “RFP,” “consolidation,” “sunsetting”). BirdDog surfaces less obvious but actionable triggers.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Why isn’t my account scoring correctly? Newly added (wait ~20-60 min), sparse public data, or weak Signals. Add more/better Signals and context; ensure domain/URL is correct.

Why aren’t signals showing results yet? They may be too narrow or brand-new. Broaden phrasing, remove disqualifiers, or give it a day for crawling.

Why do I see duplicates of an account? The same company might sit in multiple lists or use variant domains. Consolidate to a canonical domain and merge/clean lists.

Why can’t I create a new list as an admin? You may be on a restricted role or environment setting. Check permissions or ask your BirdDog admin/support to enable list creation.

How do I fix onboarding emails not sending? Verify the user exists, click Send Email again, and have the user check spam. If still blocked, contact support to confirm domain policy.

Why isn’t my CRM integration working? Confirm the CRM connection is authorized, that the account exists in your CRM, and that pop-ups/redirects aren’t blocked.

Who do I contact for support? Reach out via Slack, email, or LinkedIn (as noted in-app). Include screenshots, account URLs, and a short description.

docs.title: Advanced
docs.text:
Can I use BirdDog with custom APIs? Some advanced plans support custom hooks/integrations. Share your use case with support to review feasibility.

Can I run A/B tests with signals? Yes—make a signals with slight variations in phrasing/priority and track result volume/quality over a fixed window.

Can I rank accounts manually in addition to signals? You can adjust signal priority, which influences ranking. Manual rank nudges may be available depending on plan.

Can I track performance by signal type? Yes—monitor results count, engagement from templates tied to each signal, and downstream outcomes in your CRM reports.

docs.text: If your signals are returning results that feel too broad or irrelevant, you can refine them using Signal Improvement. By adding specific qualifications and context, you teach the BirdDog engine exactly what "good" looks like for your ICP.

docs.title: How to Refine Your Signals (0:21 – 1:30)
docs.text: There are two primary ways to make your signals more accurate:

docs.title: 1. Editing the Core Question
docs.text: Be as specific as possible in the primary signal question. * Generic: Does {account} have an Enterprise Sales Team? * Refined: Does {account} have an Enterprise Sales Team based in the U.S.? * Why it works: Adding a geographic or functional constraint directly into the question forces the AI to filter out global or irrelevant hits immediately.

docs.title: 2. Adding Additional Context
docs.text: Use the Additional Context field to provide nuanced definitions that aren't captured in a simple question. * Define Terms: Tell the system how you define a specific role (e.g., "Enterprise Sales should include Strategic Accounts or Global Account Managers"). * Set Qualifications: List specific requirements that must be met for the signal to be considered "Found."

docs.title: Common Use Cases for Improvement (1:31 – 2:00)
docs.text:
Detailed prompts lead to higher-quality signals. Here are two examples of how to tighten your criteria:

Topic Vague Signal Refined Signal + Context Funding Did {account} get funding? Question: Did {account} receive VC funding? Context: Only include Seed or Series A rounds. Exclude debt financing or grants. Hiring Is {account} hiring for sales? Question: Is {account} hiring Enterprise AEs? Context: Only include full-cycle roles targeting the Fortune 500.

docs.title: How to Apply Updates (2:01 – 2:15)
docs.text:
1. Navigate to your Signals configuration page.
  2. Click Edit on the signal you wish to improve.
  3. Update the Question or add details to the Additional Context box.
  4. Click Update.
  5. The Result: BirdDog will adjust how it evaluates all new incoming signals based on these updated rules.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: The "Negative Constraint"
docs.text: One of the fastest ways to improve a signal is to tell the system what you don't want. If you are looking for "Sales Leaders" but keep getting "Retail Store Managers," add context that says: "Exclude retail, hospitality, or branch-level management roles; focus only on B2B corporate sales leadership."

docs.title: Why Mute vs. Delete? (0:29 – 0:57)
docs.text:
Muting is the best option when a signal is useful for research but not urgent enough for an instant notification.

  • Keep the Data: Muted signals still appear on the Account Details page and within your Plays.
  • Maintain Rankings: Muted signals continue to contribute to an account's Point Score, ensuring your prioritization remains accurate.
  • Stop the Noise: You will stop receiving individual Email and Slack alerts for that specific trigger.

Example: You might want to track if an account has "Full-cycle Salespeople" to understand their structure, but you don't need a Slack alert every time a new job posting for that role is found.

docs.title: How to Mute a Signal (0:58 – 1:14)

docs.title: Getting Setup
docs.text: Getting your BirdDog account set up correctly is the fastest way to turn cold data into warm leads. By following these steps, you move from manually hunting for information to having an AI-driven system that alerts you the moment a company is ready for a conversation.

docs.title: 1. Add Your Current Accounts
docs.text:
The first thing you need to do is tell BirdDog which companies you already care about. This gives the system a starting point to learn what your "ideal customer" looks like.

  • What to do: Take a list of company website links (URLs) from your CRM (like Salesforce or HubSpot) or a spreadsheet and put them into BirdDog.
  • Why it matters: BirdDog needs to "watch" these companies to find patterns in their behavior.
  • Video Walkthrough:
  • Action: How to add accounts

docs.title: 2. Choose Your Signals
docs.text:
Signals are "events" that BirdDog looks for on the internet. Think of them as triggers that tell you a company might be ready to buy your product.

  • Common Signals: A company just got new funding, they are hiring a new Vice President of Sales, or they just opened a new office.
  • What to do: Go into your settings and mark the most important events as High. This tells BirdDog to alert you immediately when these happen.
  • Video Walkthrough:
  • Action: How to setup new signal

docs.title: 3. Turn on the "Assignment Desk" Account Recommendations
docs.text:
Once the system knows your current accounts and what signals you like, it can start hunting for new companies you’ve never heard of. This feature is called Farsight.

  • How it works: Farsight scans the entire internet. If it finds a company that looks exactly like your best customers and is showing "High" signals, it will recommend them to you.
  • Filters: You can set rules so it only finds companies of a certain size (like 50–200 employees) or in specific locations (like the United States).
  • Video Walkthrough:
  • Action: How to get recommendations

docs.title: 4. Connect to Slack and Your Calendar
docs.text:
To make sure you don't have to keep checking the BirdDog website all day, you should connect it to the tools you use for work.

  • Slack: BirdDog will send a message to your team's Slack channel the moment it finds a "High" signal.
  • Google Calendar: BirdDog will look at your upcoming meetings and email you a "Cheat Sheet" 24 hours before a call.
  • Action: Slack setup | Google Calendar setup

docs.title: 5. Organize Your "Plays"
docs.text:
As you get more accounts, you’ll want to group them. We call these Plays. A Play is just a folder that updates itself automatically based on rules you set.

  • Example Play: "New Sales Leaders." You can make a folder that only shows companies that have hired a new Sales Director in the last 3 months.
  • Video Walkthrough:
  • Action: How to create Plays

docs.title: How to Deny an Account (0:22 – 1:11)
docs.text: When you encounter a recommendation that doesn't fit, click the Deny button. You will have approximately six seconds to select a specific reason for the rejection.

docs.title: Permanent Removal Options
docs.text: Selecting any of the following will permanently remove the account from your recommendations. BirdDog will ensure this specific company never appears on your Assignment Desk again: * Wrong Size: The company is too large or too small for your current focus. * Wrong Geography: The company is headquartered outside of your selling territory. * Not ICP: The company does not match your Ideal Customer Profile.

docs.title: The "Soft" Reject: Not Exciting
docs.text:
• Not Exciting: Choosing this option tells the system that the company fits your profile, but the current signals aren't strong enough to warrant outreach right now.
  • The Result: BirdDog will hide the account temporarily but will continue to re-scan it. If the account picks up more significant signals in the future, it will be brought back to the Assignment Desk for your review.

docs.title: Why Feedback Matters (1:12 – 1:32)
docs.text: Providing feedback does more than just clean up your view; it "tweaks" the system: 1. Iterative Learning: Every time you mark an account as "Not ICP," the system adjusts its internal logic to favor accounts with different characteristics. 2. Cleaner Pipeline: It ensures your reps are only seeing accounts that are truly actionable. 3. Data Quality: Consistent feedback helps the BirdDog team identify if certain signals are returning "false positives" for your industry.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: Feedback vs. Filter Adjustments
docs.text: If you find yourself denying every second or third account for the same reason (e.g., they are all too small), don't just keep clicking Deny. Go to your Recommendation Settings and adjust the global Employee Count filter. This is a much faster way to fix systemic issues in your lead flow.

docs.title: Managing Account Status: Deleting, Archiving, & Activating
Overview
docs.text: Maintaining a clean and relevant book of business is critical for accurate signal tracking. BirdDog provides three primary ways to manage your account list: Deleting, Archiving, and Activating. Whether you are a rep cleaning up your personal view or an admin managing the entire organization's capacity, these tools ensure you are only monitoring the accounts that matter.

docs.title: User Actions: My Accounts Page (0:00 – 0:31)
docs.text:
Individual users can manage their assigned accounts directly from the main dashboard.

  1. Select Accounts: Use the checkboxes next to company names to select individual accounts, or run a Filter (e.g., Score < 10) to select a specific group.
  2. Choose Action: A bulk-action menu will appear with the following options:
    • Delete: Permanently removes the account and its historical signals from your view.
    • Archive: Removes the account from your active monitoring but keeps it in the system. This is the best way to free up capacity without losing the account data entirely.
    • Activate: If you are viewing your "Archived" list, use this to bring a company back into active monitoring.

docs.title: Admin Actions: System Setup (0:32 – 1:01)
docs.text:
Admins have a high-level view of all accounts across every user's list. This is useful for clearing out legacy data or re-balancing account loads across the team.

  1. Navigate to System Setup in the bottom-left corner.
  2. Click on Manage Accounts.
  3. Granular Management: This view lists every account currently in the platform. You can:
    • Filter by Rep/Owner to clean up a specific team member's list.
    • Filter by Last Activity or Point Score to identify dead leads.
    • Bulk-delete or archive accounts at the organizational level.

docs.text: Action Result Best For... Archive Stops active tracking; frees up a license "seat." Accounts that might be relevant later or accounts you want to keep in your CRM history. Delete Wipes the account and all associated signal data. Competitors, duplicates, or accounts that no longer fit your ICP.

docs.text: Managing your team's access is a critical part of maintaining BirdDog's security and organizational health. As an Admin, you have the ability to immediately revoke access for any user. However, deleting a user is a permanent action with significant data consequences, so it should be handled with care.

docs.title: How to Remove a User (0:00 – 0:19)
docs.text: The process is designed to be quick and definitive: 1. Navigate to the System Setup page from the bottom-left sidebar. 2. Locate the user you wish to remove from the active users list. 3. Click the Delete button next to their name. 4. The user is immediately removed from the platform.

docs.title: Critical Considerations (0:20 – 0:41)
docs.text:
Before you delete a user, it is important to understand the downstream effects:

  • Account Removal: All accounts currently assigned specifically to that user will be removed from your organization's active monitoring list.
  • Credential Revocation: The user will immediately lose their login access and can no longer view or interface with BirdDog data.
  • Permanent Action: Deletion is not a "pause." If you wish to bring a team member back later, you will need to recreate their profile from scratch, re-authenticate their integrations, and re-add their entire account list.

docs.title: Pro-Tip: Offboarding Best Practices
docs.text:
If a rep is leaving the company but you want to keep their accounts and signal history, do not delete them immediately.

Instead, use the Manage Accounts tool in System Setup to re-assign their accounts to a different team member or a manager first. Once the accounts have been safely moved to a new owner, you can proceed with deleting the user without losing your valuable research and tracking data.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Salesforce integration connects BirdDog directly with your CRM, keeping your accounts, opportunities, and BirdDog Signals automatically synced.

With this integration, reps can see BirdDog’s enriched account data and scores inside Salesforce, while BirdDog continuously learns from your pipeline activity.

docs.title: Why It Matters
docs.text:
Integrating BirdDog with your CRM allows for two major benefits:

  1. Automatic syncing of the accounts in your CRM with BirdDog’s scores and data. This keeps BirdDog insights accessible in Salesforce without requiring manual uploads or spreadsheets.

  2. Smarter signals for every deal stage. BirdDog dynamically adjusts the information it provides based on deal stage — helping reps focus on what’s most relevant whether they’re qualifying or closing.

To achieve the first benefit, BirdDog needs access to Accounts in your CRM. To achieve the second, BirdDog also requires access to Opportunities.

docs.title: Setup (0:00 – 0:34)
docs.text:
1. Log into BirdDog.
  2. Navigate to Settings → Integrations in the lower-left corner.
  3. Scroll down to the Integrations module and select Salesforce.
  4. Choose your environment:
  5. Default for production.
  6. Sandbox for testing.
  7. Click Submit to start the connection.

You’ll be redirected to Salesforce to log in with your Integration User credentials.

docs.title: Authentication & Integration Pattern
docs.text:
Most BirdDog clients follow this standard integration pattern:

  • Create or use an Integration User with permission to view and edit required objects and fields.
  • The Integration User authenticates through BirdDog’s OAuth flow using BirdDog’s Salesforce Connected App.
  • After authentication, they map CRM fields to BirdDog fields inside the BirdDog Platform.

Once connected, BirdDog will: - Pull accounts and opportunities from Salesforce. - Push enriched BirdDog data back to Salesforce fields. - Perform these operations automatically in daily batches.

When new accounts are uploaded or activated in BirdDog, the platform will immediately push updates to Salesforce.

docs.title: Connected App & OAuth Flow
docs.text:
BirdDog uses a Salesforce Connected App hosted within BirdDog’s org. When your first user connects, Salesforce automatically creates a shadow copy of that app in your own org (visible under Setup → App Manager).

No package installation is required.

docs.title: Revoking Access

docs.title: Rate Limits
docs.text:
BirdDog performs at least one daily batch push and pull operation. Occasional additional syncs occur when users upload new accounts or trigger manual refreshes.

Typical clients find ~100 API calls per day more than sufficient.

During the first week, expect increased sync frequency while the integration calibrates with your CRM.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Signals are the specific "triggers" BirdDog looks for to identify a high-value opportunity. While BirdDog comes with a set of default signals, Admins have the power to create custom signals tailored to their specific Ideal Customer Profile (ICP). If you can ask it as a question, BirdDog can find the answer across the web.

docs.title: How to Create a New Signal (0:00 – 1:13)
docs.text:
1. Access Settings: Log into BirdDog and navigate to the System Setup page (Admin only).
  2. Configure Signals: Click on Configure Signals. You will see your active list or a blank slate.
  3. Add Signal: Click the Add Signal button.
  4. The Bracket Syntax: When writing your question, you must use the {account} bracket syntax.
    • Example: Does {account} have an enterprise sales team?
  5. Title it: Give your signal a clear name (e.g., "Has Enterprise Sales Team").
  6. Add: Click Add.

Processing Note: Once a new signal is added, it won't show results immediately. It takes 1 to 2 hours for the system to re-scan your existing accounts and populate the findings.

docs.title: Signal Management & Importance (1:14 – 1:53)
docs.text:
Once a signal is created, you can control how it impacts your dashboard and notifications:

  • Priority (High/Low): * High: Signals marked as High will heavily influence the Point Score and cause the account to be recommended more frequently.
    • Low: These will be tracked but won't significantly move the needle on an account's overall score.
  • Muting: You can toggle notifications for specific signals. This is useful if you want to track a data point for research purposes without getting an alert every time it’s found.
  • Editing: You can refine the phrasing of your signal at any time to improve accuracy.

docs.title: Data Sources: Where BirdDog Looks (2:08 – 2:23)
docs.text: BirdDog scans a massive array of public data to answer your signal questions. For a signal to be successful, the information must live within these sources: * Job Postings: (The #1 source for internal strategy shifts). * Company Websites: Product pages, "About Us," and blogs. * Financial Reports: Earnings calls and 10-K/10-Q reports. * Public News: Press releases and news articles. * Social Posts: Official company updates.

docs.title: Signals Guide
docs.text: A practical, copy-pasteable playbook for writing A+ signals that your team can use today.

docs.title: What is a “Signal” in BirdDog?
docs.text:
A signal is a yes/no question you ask BirdDog about a specific company. BirdDog then hunts across public sources (news, press releases, job postings, company websites, earnings calls/reports, etc.) and returns matches with summaries, sources, and next steps.

Golden rules 1. Include the account token in brackets → Does {account} … ? 2. Ask a yes/no question (start with Does or Is) 3. Keep it specific and observable in public sources 4. Use BirdDog Context to add nuance (e.g., regions, role levels, exclusions) 5. Prioritize the most valuable signals (set to High when it should drive action)

docs.title: Anatomy of a Great Signal
docs.text:
Pattern: Does {account} <observable behavior or announcement> <with qualifiers> ?

Examples of good qualifiers - What (product, team, program, policy) - Where (US, EU, APAC, specific states/countries) - Who (roles, leadership titles) - When (recently, newly, announced/launch/hiring now) - Why/Impact (expansion, consolidation, pilot, migration)

Use BirdDog Context to refine

“Only include results from US or Europe; prioritize junior to mid-level roles; exclude staffing agencies.”

docs.title: Quick Start: 25 “Starter Pack” Signals (copy-paste)
docs.text:
Use these to cover the essentials. Mark priority = High for your top 5–8.

  1. Does {account} have any mergers or acquisitions (M&A) in progress or recently announced?
  2. Has {account} announced new venture capital or private equity funding?
  3. Is {account} expanding into a new market or geography?
  4. Has {account} appointed new leadership (CEO, CRO, CMO, CIO, CISO, VP Sales, VP Marketing)?
  5. Has {account} launched any new products or major features?
  6. Is {account} hiring multiple sales roles (AEs/SDRs) at once?
  7. Is {account} hiring roles related to digital transformation or modernization?
  8. Is {account} hiring data, AI/ML, or analytics roles?
  9. Is {account} hiring security or compliance roles?
  10. Has {account} opened a new office or facility?
  11. Has {account} announced layoffs, restructuring, or a reorg?
  12. Is {account} migrating to or standardizing on a specific cloud provider?
  13. Does {account} mention vendor consolidation or tool rationalization?
  14. Is {account} running pilots or proofs of concept (POCs)?
  15. Has {account} issued an RFP or tender in our category?
  16. Does {account} mention new partnerships or alliances?
  17. Has {account} won government or enterprise contracts recently?
  18. Is {account} pursuing certifications or audits (SOC 2, ISO 27001, FedRAMP, HIPAA)?
  19. Has {account} announced a strategic initiative or transformation program?
  20. Has {account} reported material changes in earnings calls related to our solution area?
  21. Is {account} adopting or sunsetting relevant technologies or platforms?
  22. Is {account} expanding headcount rapidly in our ICP functions?
  23. Does {account} mention intent data, account research, or programmatic outbound?
  24. Has {account} entered new vertical segments or customer tiers?
  25. Is {account} experiencing incidents or outages that may drive urgency?

Tip: If a starter signal is noisy, add a disqualifier (see section below) and/or refine with Context.

docs.text:
Create explicit “no-go” signals to keep your feed clean. These are still yes/no, but you’ll mute or treat them as negative filters.

  • Is {account} a consumer-only (B2C) brand with no B2B motion (disqualify)?

  • Is {account} expanding into <market/region>?

  • Pain (pipeline growth, enablement, compliance, modernization)
  • Trigger (new leader, hiring burst, regulation, outage) Signal: Does {account} have a new CISO and mention security modernization or compliance gaps?

docs.title: C. Buying Stage Ladder
docs.text:

  • Consideration → hiring/programs/budgets
  • Decision → RFPs, pilots, platform choices Signals:

docs.title: BirdDog Context: Make It Smarter
docs.text:
Use the Context box on a signal to coach BirdDog: - “Only include US & EU, exclude agencies and resellers.” - “Prioritize job postings that indicate ‘build from scratch’, ‘migration’, or ‘greenfield’.” - “Consider variants of the company name and product brands.”

This keeps the signal wording simple, while your Context adds nuance.

  • Migration Is {account} migrating from legacy <platform> to <new platform>?
  • Consolidation Does {account} plan to consolidate <tool category> to reduce cost?

  • Earnings signal Has {account} cited investments or constraints in <theme> during earnings calls?

docs.title: Templates Library (fill-in-the-blanks)
docs.text:
General - Does {account} mention <initiative/topic> in recent announcements? - Is {account} hiring <role/function> to drive <goal>? - Has {account} launched <program/product> for <market/segment>?

Go-to-Market - Does {account} require reps to conduct account research or use intent data? - Is {account} expanding outbound teams or territories?

Technology - Is {account} standardizing on <cloud/data/security> platforms? - Has {account} deprecated or sunset <tool> in favor of <tool>?

Operations / Finance - Does {account} mention cost optimization or vendor consolidation? - Has {account} established a center of excellence for <function>?

Risk / Compliance - Is {account} pursuing <SOC 2/ISO/FedRAMP/HIPAA> compliance? - Has {account} cited regulatory pressure in <region/industry>?

Pro move: Pair each template with Context (region/role/recency) and set High priority if it should change rep behavior today.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Your Signals
docs.text:
Too few results? - Use broader terms; remove niche jargon. - Split one complex signal into two simpler ones. - Add variants to Context (synonyms, brand names, acronyms).

Too noisy? - Add a disqualifier signal (e.g., exclude agencies). - Add qualifiers (leadership level, geography, role seniority). - Use Context to specify “must include ”.

Unclear actionability? - Tie each signal to a template and next step (e.g., SDR email, AE call, CRM task). - Mark non-actionable “FYI” signals to Normal priority, actionable to High.

docs.title: Quality Checklist (before you hit “Add”)
docs.text:
• ✅ Starts with Does/Is and includes {account}
  • ✅ Observable in public sources BirdDog covers
  • ✅ Priority matches the revenue impact
  • ✅ Linked to an email template (for top signals)

docs.title: Worked Examples (from rough idea → final signal)
docs.text:
Idea: “I care when they’re hiring lots of salespeople.” - Draft: Is {account} hiring salespeople? - Better: Is {account} hiring **multiple** sales roles (AEs/SDRs) at once? - Context: “US & EU, exclude staffing agencies; prioritize postings that mention ‘new logo acquisition’ or ‘prospecting’.” - Priority: High

Idea: “I want to know about vendor consolidation.” - Draft: Does {account} mention vendor consolidation? - Better: Does {account} mention consolidating or rationalizing tools in <our category>? - Context: “Look for terms: ‘consolidate vendors’, ‘tool rationalization’, ‘platform standardization’.” - Priority: High

docs.title: Keep Iterating
docs.text:
• Start with the Starter Pack + 3–5 ICP-specific signals.
  • Review results after a week → refine wording and Context.
  • Promote your best performers to High priority and connect templates.
  • Retire or mute weak signals; add disqualifiers to reduce noise.
  • Pair with Farsight (Auto-Add) to keep your lists full of strong-fit accounts.

Need help? Drop us a note and we’ll review your first 10–15 signals and suggest improvements tailored to your ICP, motion, and territories.

docs.text: The Slack integration ensures that you never miss a high-intent signal. Instead of manually checking the dashboard, BirdDog pushes real-time alerts for new signals, account assignments, and recommendations directly into your Slack workflow.

docs.title: Setting Up Personalized Tags (0:10 – 1:01)
docs.text:
To ensure BirdDog mentions you specifically when one of your accounts hits a signal, you need to sync your Slack Member ID with the BirdDog platform.

  1. Find your Member ID:
    • Open Slack and click on your Profile Picture in the sidebar or a message.
    • Click the three dots (More) on your profile card.
    • Select Copy Member ID (This is a unique alphanumeric code).
  2. Sync with BirdDog:
    • Navigate to Settings → Integrations in BirdDog.
    • Locate the Slack section and paste your ID into the Member ID field.
  3. Result: You will now be automatically tagged (@user) in the shared Slack channel whenever there is an update relevant to your book of business.

docs.title: Private Notifications: Reducing "Channel Noise" (1:02 – 1:24)
docs.text:
If your team's shared Slack channel is high-volume, you can enable Private Access to receive a curated feed of alerts.

  • How it works: Flick the Allow Private Access toggle to "On" in your BirdDog settings.
  • The Result: The BirdDog Bot will send you Direct Messages (DMs) containing only the signals and recommendations for accounts assigned to you. This keeps your notifications clean and focused exclusively on your targets.

docs.title: Troubleshooting & Access (1:25 – 1:41)
docs.text:
• Missing Channel: Every BirdDog organization should have a dedicated Slack channel (e.g., #birddog-signals). If you have not been invited to yours, please contact the team.
  • Bot Permissions: Ensure the BirdDog Bot has been added to your specific channel to allow it to post updates.

docs.text: Notification Content New Signal Found Instant alert when an account hits a "High" importance trigger. Account Recommendation Alert from the Assignment Desk when Farsight finds a new prospect. Account Assignment Notification when a manager assigns a new account to your profile.
